Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Improving the Aeroacoustic Properties of Hybrid Anechoic Wind Tunnels

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: Wind tunnels are a fundamental part of the engineering and scientific process used to develop quieter and more efficient aircraft, wind turbines, and other systems. The hybrid anechoic wind tunnel, introduced some 13 years ago, provides a way to substantially increase the accuracy and scope of wind tunnel tests concerned with flow generated noise. This configuration, which has already been adopted by a number of research facilities across the world relies on “acoustic windows” – large panels of tensioned fabric that are transparent to sound but largely impervious to flow. Such windows have been made from commercially available Kevlar fabric which has many desirable characteristics for this purpose, but the fabric was designed for composites manufacture. A Kevlar fabric explicitly designed for wind tunnel applications promises additional benefits – an even quieter test environment and embedded instrumentation that can monitor the flow. Under this project, an interdisciplinary team of textiles, acoustics, and aerodynamics researchers will conduct a short-term research program to develop these materials. This innovative, potentially high payoff effort, promises to bring the advantages of hybrid anechoic testing to national scale facilities and greatly enhance the development quieter and more efficient vehicles and systems. This project will also be dedicated to research education at the postdoc, graduate and undergraduate levels. <br/><br/>This research is based upon the observation that Kevlar fabric used as acoustic windows generates noise at high frequencies (>10kHz) that potentially limits the application of this technology in the context of national scale wind tunnel facilities that perform applied model scale testing for vehicle development by industry and government. The hypothesis is that the noise is made by pores in the fabric that serve no useful aeroacoustic function. Adjusting the weave to eliminate the pores requires the multi-disciplinary collaboration needed to perform a systematic study of the optimum fabric design for aeroacoustic applications. The work is being performed by a team of researchers from Virginia Tech, Florida Atlantic University, and NC State. The NC State group will use a research loom fabricate the needed modified fabrics and also investigate the feasibility of embedding sensors. Wind tunnel experiments directed at documenting and understanding the aeroacoustic performance of the fabrics will be performed at Virginia Tech, which will also provide input on sensor choices and requirements. Theoretical modeling and understanding of the nature of the acoustic source will be performed at Florida Atlantic University. Together this effort is expected to generate robust recommendations for optimal acoustic window design and embedded sensors that can be adopted by current and planned hybrid anechoic wind tunnels.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
To assess noise generated by aerodynamic bodies, such as wind turbine blades, propellers, aircraft wings, etc., small-scaled wind tunnel tests are often performed, where the generated noise is measured and then the findings of the scaled tests are used to model or predict the noise emissions of large-scale aerodynamic objects. A novel but fundamental test bed of aeroacoustic noise measurements are Kevlar-walled wind tunnels where Kevlar confines the flow in the wind tunnel while it lets the sound generated by the test object to pass through with minimal acoustic losses. However, Kevlar was found to introduce an unwanted self-noise at higher frequencies, which is of particular interest for scaled aircraft tests. Additionally, currently-used Kevlar fabrics were chosen during the development phase of Kevlar-walled tunnels without performing detailed aeroacoustic studies of porous fabrics. For these reasons, our goals were to identify links between porous fabric properties and their aeroacoustic performance. The aim is to find porous fabrics that can offer lower acoustic losses and lower self-noise levels than currently used Kevlar fabrics. It was found that the open area ratio (OAR) of porous fabrics is closely correlated with the transmission loss of the fabric, with higher OAR resulting in lower transmission loss levels. However, we have also showed that a fabric superior to the currently available Kevlar fabrics must still rely on pores to deliver acceptable transmission loss levels. The frequency range of the generated fabric self-noise was found to be primarily linked with the thread density (threads per inch, TPI) of the fabric while the OAR played a secondary role. It was found that fabrics with higher TPI generated self-noise over higher frequencies. Overall, it was found that a fabric with increased thread density and a few percent open area ratio (<10%) can outperform the currently available Kevlar fabrics. This new, theoretical fabric is expected to shift the self-noise to higher frequencies while sustaining a low level of transmission loss. 


Last Modified: 03/01/2022
Modified by: William J Devenport
